Within heart pants, nor leaps the eye nor lips:
Prepare yourselves to kiss for you must be kissed.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: By my troth 'tis a pretty thing to be towards marriage, a pretty loving: look where he comes ha ha.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Good day sweet love.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: Wish her good night man.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Good morrow sister.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: A curtsy to you caper, tomorrow morn I'll call you brother.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: But much much falls betwixt the cup and lip.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: Be not to confident the knot may slip.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Bounty, blessedness, and the spirit of wine attend my mistress.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: Thanks good chub.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: God ye good morrow heartily mistress, and how do you since last I saw you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: God's me you must not inquire how she does, that's privy counsel, fie, there's manners indeed.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Pray you pardon my incivility, I was somewhat bold with you, but believe me I'll never be so saucy to ask you how you do again, as long as I live la.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: Square chub, what sullen black is that.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p:
A tassel that hangs at my purse strings, he dogs me and I give him scraps and pay for his ordinary, feed him, he liquours himself in the juice of my bounty, and when he hath sucked up strength of spirit he squeezeth it in my own face, when I have refined and sharpened his wits with good food, he cuts my
fingers, and breaks jests upon me, I bear them, and beat him: but by this light the dull eyed thinks he dos well, dos very well, and but that he and I are of two faithes — I fill my belly, and feeds his brain, I could find in my heart to hug him, to hug him.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Prithee persuade him to assume spirit and salute us.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Lampatho, Lampatho, art out of countenance, for wit's sake salute these beauties, how dost like them?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Uds fut, I can liken them to nothing, but great men's great horse upon great days, whose tails are trussed up in silk and silver.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: To them man, salute them.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Bless you fair ladies, God make you all his servants.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: God make you all his servants.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: He is holpen well had need of you, for be it spoken without profanism he hath more in this train, I fear me you ha' more servants than he, I am sure the devil is an angel of darkness.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I but those are angels of light.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Light angels, prithee leave them, withdraw a little and hear a sonnet prithee, hear a sonnet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Made of Albanos widow that was, and monsieur Laverdure's wife that must be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Come leave his lips and command some liquor, if you have no bottle-ale, command some claret-wine and borage, for that's my predominate humour sleek billed Bacchus, let's fill thy guts.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay hear it, and relish it judiciously.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I do relish it most judicially. Quad. drinks.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Adored excellence, delicious sweet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Delicious sweet good, very good.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: If thou canst taste the purer juice of love.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: If thou canst taste the purer juice, good still, good still.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I do relish it, it tastes sweet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Is not the metaphor good, is't not well followed?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Passing good, very pleasing.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Is't not sweet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Let me see't I'll make it sweet,
I'll soak it in the juice of Helicon.
By'r lady, passing sweet, good, passing sweet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: You wrong my muse.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The Irish flux upon thy muse, thy whorish muse,
Here is no place for her loose brothelry,
We will not deal with her, go, away, away,

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: I'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: How prithee in a play? come, come, be sociable
In private severance from society,
Here leaps a vain of blood inflamed with love,
Mounting to pleasure, all addict to mirth,
Thou'lt read a satire or a sonnet now,
Clagging their airy humour with —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lamp oil, watch candles, rug-gowns and small juice,
Thin commons, four o'clock rising, I renounce you all,
Now may I ternally abandon meat
Rust fusty you which most embraced disuse,
You a made me an ass, thus shaped my lot,
I am a mere scholar, that is a mere sot.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Come then lamp, I'll pour fresh oil into thee,
Apply thy spirit that it may nimbly turn,
Unto the habit, fashion of the age,
I'll make thee man the scholar, enable thy behaviour,
Apt for the entertain of any presence:
I'll turn thee gallant, first thou shalt have a mistress,
How is thy spirit raised to yonder beauty?
She with the sanguine cheek, the dimpled chin,
The pretty amorous smile that clips her lips,
And dallies bought her cheek —
She with the speaking eye,
That casts out beams as ardent as those flakes,
Which singed the world by rash brained Phaeton,
She with the lip, oh lips! she for whose sake,
A man could find in his heart to in-hell himself,
There's more philosophy, more theorems,
More demonstrations, all invincible,
More clear divinity drawn on her cheek,
then in all volumes tedious paraphrase,
Of musty eld, oh who would staggering doubt,
The soul's eternity, seeing it hath
Of heavenly beauty, but to case it up,
Who would distrust a supreme existence,
Able to confound when it can create,
Such heaven on earth able to entrance,
Amaze: oh I 'tis providence, not chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now by the front of Jove methinks her eye
Shoots more spirit in me, oh beauty feminine!
How powerful art thou, what deep magic lies
Within the circle of thy speaking eyes.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why now could I eat thee, thou dost please mine appetite, I can desist thee, God made thee a good fool, and happy and ignorant, and amorous, and rich and frail, and a satirist, and an essayist, and sleepy, and proud, and indeed a fool and than thou shalt be sure of all these. Do but scorn her she is thine own, accost her carelessly, and her eye promiseth she will be bound to the good abbearing.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Now sister Meletza dost mark their craft, some straggling thoughts transport thy attentiveness from his discourse, waste Iacomo's or our brother's plot?

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Both, both, sweet lady, my page heard all, we met the rogue, so like Albano, I beat the rogue.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I but when you were gone the rogue beat me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Now take my counsel, listen.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: A pretty youth, a pretty well shaped youth, a good leg, a very good eye, a sweet ingenious face, and I warrant a good wit, nay which is more, if he be poor I assure my soul he is chaste and honest, good faith I fancy, I fancy him, I and I may chance, well I'll think the rest.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I say be careless still, court her without compliment take spirit.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: Wert not a pleasing jest for me to clothe
Another rascal like Albano, say
And rumor him returned without all deceit,
would not beget errors most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Meletza bella belletza, madonna, bella bella genteletza prithee kiss this initiated gallant.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: How would it please you I should respect ye.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: As any thing, what you will as nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: As nothing, how will you value my love.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Why just as you respect me, as nothing, for out of nothing, nothing is bred, so nothing shall not beget anything, anything bring nothing, nothing bring anything, anything and nothing shall be what you will, my speech mounting to the value of myself which is.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: What sweet —

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Your nothing light as yourself senseless as your sex, and just as you would ha' me, nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Your wit skips a morisco, but by the brightest spangle of my tier, I vouchsafe you entire unaffected favour, were this gentle spirit be not proud.
sp.l: Believe it youth slow speech, swift love doth often shroud.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: My soul's entranced your favour doth transport,
My sense passed sense, by your adored graces,
I dote, am rapt.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Nay if you fall to passion and past sense,
My breasts no harbour for your love, go pack, hence.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Uds fut thou gull, thou inky scholar, ha, thou whoreson fop,
Wilt not thou clap into our fashioned gallantry,
Couldst not be proud and scornful, loof and vain
Gods my heart's object, what a plague is this:
My soul's entranced, fut couldst not clip and kiss,
My soul's entranced, ten thousand crowns at least
Lost lost, my soul's entranced, loves life oh beast!

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Celia open, open Celia, I would enter, open Celia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Celia, open, open Celia, I would enter open Celia.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Uds f, f, f, fut let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Uds f, f, f, fut let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Sweet breast you ha' played the wag i'faith.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Believe it sweet not I.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Come you have attired some fiddler like Albano to fright the perfumer, there's the jest.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Good fortunes to our sister.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: And a speedy marriage.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Then we must wish her no good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: For shame, for shame straight clear your house; sweep out this dust, fling out this trash, return to modesty your husband I say your husband Albano that was supposed drowned is returned I and at the door.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Ha ha, my husband, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Laugh you, shameless? laugh you?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come, come, your plots discovered, good faith kinsmen I am no scold: to shape a perfumer like my husband, oh sweet jest.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Last hopes all known.

sp.speaker: Celi
sp.p: For penance of your fault will you maintain a jest now, my love hath tired some fiddler like Albano, like the perfumer.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not I by blessedness not I.

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: Come 'tis true, do but support the jest and you shall surfeit, with laughter.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.l: Faith we condescend, 'twill not be crossed I see,
Marriage and hanging go by destiny.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: B, b, b, bar out Albano, oh adulterous impudent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: B, b, b, bar out Albano, oh thou matchless g, g, g, giglet.

div.stage: Enter Albano and Francisco.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Let them in, let them in, now, now, now observe, observe, look, look, look.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: That same's a fiddler, shaped like thee, fear naught, be confident thou shalt know the jest hereafter, be confident; fear naught, blush not, stand firm.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p:
Now brothers, now gallants, now sisters now call a perfumer a gutter-master, bar me my house, beat me: baffle
me, scoff me, deride me, ha that I were a young man again, by the mass I would ha' you all by the ears, by the mass la; I am Francisco Soranza am I not giglet: strumpet, cutters, swaggerers, brothel haunters, I am Francisco, oh god, oh slaves, oh dogs, dogs, curs.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: No sir pray you pardon us, we confess you are not Francisco nor a perfumer, but even.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: But even Albano.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: But even a fiddler, a minikin tickler, a pum, pum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A scraper, scraper.
Art not ashamed before Albanos face,
To clip his spouse, oh shameless impudent!

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Well said perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: A fiddler a scraper, a minikin tickler, a pum, a pum, even now a perfumer, now a fiddler, I will be even what you will, do, do do, k, k, k, kiss my wife be, be, be, be, fore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why wouldst have him kiss her behind?

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Before my own f, f, f, face.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Well done fiddler.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: I'll f, f, fiddle ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dost f, f, flout me.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Dost m, m, m, mock me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll to the Duke I'll p, p, p, paste up infamies on every post.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: 'Twas rarely, rarely done, away, away. Exit Francisco.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: I'll f, f, follow, though I st, st, st, stut, I'll stumble to the Duke in p, p, plain language, I pray you use my wife well, good faith she was a kind soul and an honest woman once, I was her husband and was called Albano before I was drowned, but now after my resurrection I an I know not what indeed brothers, and indeed sisters and in deed wife I am: what you will, dost thou laugh, dost thou ge, ge, ge, girn; a p, p, p, perfumer a fiddler, a diabalo, matre de dios, I'll f, f, f, firk you by the lord now, now I will. Exit Albano.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Ha ha 'tis a good rogue, a good rogue.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A good rogue ha, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: No good sweet love come come dissemble not,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay if you dread nothing happy be my lot
Come via sest, come fair cheeks, come let's dance,
The sweets of love is amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: All friends, all happy friends, my veins are light,

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: Thy prayers are now god send it quickly night.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: And then come morning.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: I that's the hopeful day ▪

sp.speaker: Melancholic
sp.p: I there thou hitst it.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Pray God he hit it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Play.

div.stage: The dance.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: They say there's revels and a play at court.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A play tonight ?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I 'tis this gallants wit,

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Is't good is't good?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I fear 'twill hardly hit.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I like thy fear, well, 'twill have better chance,
There's naught more hateful than rank ignorance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come gallants the table spread will you to dinner?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Yes first a main at dice and then we'll eat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly the best wits have the bad'st fortune at dice still.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Whole play, whole play.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not I, in truth I have still exceeding bad fortune at dice.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Come shall we in, in faith thou art sudden sad,
Dost fear the shadow of my long dead lord.

sp.speaker: Lauer,
sp.l: Shadow ha' I cannot tell
Time trieth all things well. well, well.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Would I were time then, I thought 'twas for some thing that the old fornicator was bald behind; go pass on pass on.

div.head: Scae. 1.
div.stage: The curtains are drawn by a page, and Celia and Laverdure, Quadratus, and Lyzabetta, Lampatho and Meletza Simplicius, and Lucea displayed sitting at dinner. The song is sung, during which a page whispers with Simplicius.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Feed and be fat my fair Calipolis,
Rivo here's good juice, fresh Borage boy?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I commend, commend myself to ye lady.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: In troth sir you dwell far from neighbours that are enforced to commend yourself.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why Simplicius, whether now man, for good fashion's sake stir not, fit still, sit still.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I must needs rise, much good do it you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Dost thou think thy rising will do them much good, sit still, sit still, carve me of that good Melletza: fill Bacchus fill.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I must needs be gone, and you'll come to my chamber tomorrow morning, I'll send you a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: In the name of prosperity, what tide of happiness so suddenly is flowed upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll keep a horse and four boys with grace of fortune now.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Now then i'faith get up and ride.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I do not? I'll thwack a jerkin till he groan again with gold lace: let me see, what should I desire of God, marry a cloak lined with rich taffeta, white satin suit, and my gilt rapier from pawn, nay she shall give me a chain of pearl that shall pay for all, good boy, good signior, good boy, good signior.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p:
Why now, thou speaketh in the most embraced fashion that our time hugs, no sooner a good fortune, or a fresh suit falls upon a fellow that would ha' been gulled to ha' should into your society, but and he met you he fronts you with a faint eye, throws a squint glance over a wried shoulder and cries
twixt the teeth, as very parsimonious of breath, good boy, good signior, good boy, good signior death: I will search the life blood of your hopes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And a fresh pearl-colour silk stocking oh iiii, I'll go to the half crown ordinary every meal, I'll have my ivory box of tobacco, I'll converse with none but counts and courtiers — now good boy, good signior, a pair of massy silver spurs, to a hatch short sword, and then your embroidered hanger, and good signior.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Shut the windows, darken the room, fetch whips, the fellow is mad, he raves, he raves, talks idly, lunatic, who procures thy —

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: One that has eat fat capon, sucked the boiled chicken, and let out his wit with the fool of bounty, one Fabius, I'll scorn him, he goes upon Fridaies in black satin.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Fabius, by this light, a cogging cheater, he lives on love of merchant's wives, he stands on the base, of maines, he furnisheth your ordinary, for which he feeds scotfree, keeps fair gold in his purse, to put on upon maines, by which he lives and keeps a fair boy at his heels, he is damned Fabius.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He is a fine man la, and has a good wit for when he list he can go in black satin, I and in a cloak lined with unshorn velvet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: By the salvation of humanity he's more pestilent than the plague of lice that fell upon Egypt, thou hast been knave if thou credit it, thou art an ass if thou follow it, and shalt be a perpetual idiot if thou pursue it, renounce the world, the flesh, the devil, and thy trust in men's wives for they will double with thee, and so I betake myself to the sucking of the juice capon, my ingle bottle-ale, and his gentleman usher that squires him red herring, a fool I found thee and a fool I leave thee, bear record heaven 'tis against the providence of my speech, God boy good signior.

div.stage: Enter slip Nows, doit, and Bydet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, God boy good signior, what a fool 'tis, ha, ha, what an ass 'tis, save you young gentlemen, is she coming, will she meet me, shall's encounter ha?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You were not leapt in your mother's smock, you ha' not a good cheek, an enticing eye, a smooth skin, a well shaped leg, a fair hand, you cannot bring a wench into a fool's paradise for you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not I by this garter, I am a fool, a very ninny I, how call you her? how call you her?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Call her, you rise on your right side today marry, call her, her name is mistress perpetuana, she is not very fair, nor goes extraordinary gay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: She has a good skin?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: A good skin? she is wealthy, her husbands a fool, she'll make you, she wears the breeches: she'll make you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll keep two men and they shall be tailors, they shall make suits continually, and those shall be cloth of silver.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You may go in beaten precious stones every day, marry I must acquaint you with some observances which you must pursue most religiously, she has a fool, a natural fool weights on her, that is indeed her pander to him, at the first you must be bounteous, whatsoever he craves, be it your hat, cloak, rapier, purse, or such trifle, give't, give't, the night will pay all: and to draw all suspect, from pursuing her love for base gain's sake.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Give't by this light, I'll give't, wert, gain, I care not for her chain of pearl, only her love; gain? the first thing her bounty shall fetch is my blush colour satin suit from pawn: gain?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: When you hear one wind a cornet, she is coming down saint marks street, prepare your speech, suck your lips, lighten your spirits, fresh your blood, sleek your cheeks, for now thou shalt be made for ever (A perpetual and eternal gull) Exit Bydet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I shall so ravish her with my courtship, I have such variety of discourse, such copy of phrase to begin, as this; sweet lady Ulysses dog after his masters ten years travel, I shall so tickle her, or thus, pure beauty there is a stone.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Two stones man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Called, 'tis no matter what; I ha' the eloquence, I am not to seek I warrant you.
The cornet is winded, enter Pippo Bydet, Pippo attired like a merchant's wife, and Bydet like a foole.sweet lady Ulysses dog, there's a stone called —, oh lord what shall I say.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Is all your eloquence come to this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The glorious radiant of your glimmering eyes, your glittering beauties blind my wit, and dazzled my —

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: I'll put on my mask and please you, pray you wink, pray you.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: O fine man, my mistress loves you best, I dreamt you ga' me this sword and dagger, I love your hat and feather, o.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Do not cry man, do not cry man, thou shalt ha' them I and they were —

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: O that purse with all the white pence in it, fine man I love you, give you the fine red pence soon at night, he, I thank you where's the fool now?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He has all my money, I have to keep myself, and —

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Poght.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Sir the fool shall lead you to my house, the fool shall not, at night I expect you, till then take this seal of my affection.

sp.speaker: Within Qua.
sp.p: What Simplicius.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I come Quadratus, gentlemen as yet I can but thank you, but I must be trusted for my ordinary soon at night, or stay I'll — the fool has unfurnished me, but 'twill come again, good boy.

sp.speaker: Within, Qua.
sp.p: What ho Simplicius?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Good boy, good boys, I come, I come, good boys, good boys.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: The fool shall weight on thee, now do I merit to be yclept Bosphoros Carmelydon Honorificacuminos Bydett, who who has any square dice?

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Marry sir that have I.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Thou shalt lose thy share for it in our purchase.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: I pray you now, pray you now.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Sooner the whistle of a mariner,
Shall sleek the rough curbs of the ocean back,
now speak I like myself thou shalt lose thy share.

div.stage: Enter Quadratus, Laverdure and Celia, Simplicius Meletza, Lyzabetta Lucea and Lampatho.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Ha take all then, ha.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Without cloak or hat or rapier sigh,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: God's me, look yonder, who gave you these things?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Mistress Perpetuano's fool.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mistress Perpetuano's fool, ha, ha, there lies a jest, signior the fool promised me he would not leave me.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: I know the fool well, he will stick to you, dos not use to forsake any youth that is enamoured on another man's wife, he strives to keep company with a crimson satin suit continually, he loves to be all one with a critic, a good wit self conceited, a hawk bearer, a dog keeper, and great with the nobility, he dotes upon a mere scholar an honest flat fool, but above all he is all one with a fellow whose cloak hath a better inside then his outside, and his body richer lined than his brain.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Uds so I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Pray you master pardon me, I must lose my share.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Give me my purse again.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You gave it me and I'll kept.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Well done my honest crack thou shalt be my ingle fort.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He shall keep all maugre thy beardless chin thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I may go starve till midsummer quarter.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Fool get thee hence,

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I'll to school again that I will, I left in ass in presenti, and I'll begin in ass in presenti and so good night fair gentry.

div.stage: Exit Pippo.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The triple idiot's coxcomb crowns thee,
Bitter epigrams confound thee.
Cuckold be when ere thou bride thee,
Through every comic scene be drawn,
Never come thy clothes from pawn.
Never may thy shame be sheathed,
Never kiss a wench sweet breathed.

div.stage: Cornets sound.
Enter as many pages with torches as you can, Randolfo and Adrian, Jacomo bore, the Duke with attendants.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Seance the Duke approacheth 'tis almost night,
For the Duke's up, now begins his day
Come grace his entrance; lights lights now begins our play.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Still these same bawling pipes, sound softer strains
Slumber our sense, tut these are vulgar strains,
Cannot your trembling wires throw a chain
Of powerful rapture bout our mazed sense
Why is our chair thus cushioned tapestry
Why is our bed tired with wanton sports?
Why are we clothed in glistering attiers,
If common bloods can hear, can, feel,
Can sit as soft, lie as lascivious
Stut all as rich as the greatest potentate,
Soul, and you cannot feast my thristing ears
With aught but what the lip of common birth can taste,
Take all away your labours idly waste
What sport for night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A comedy, entitled temperance.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What sot elects that subject for the court,
What should dame Temperance do here, away,
The itch on temperance your moral play.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Duke, prince, royal blood, thou that hast the best means to be damned of any lord in Venice, thou great man, let me kiss thy flesh, I am fat and therefore faithful, I will do that which few of thy subjects do; love thee, but I will never do, that which all thy subjects do; flatter thee, thy humours real, good, a comedy?
sp.l: No and thy sense would banquet in delights,
Appropriate to the blood of emperors;
Peculiar to the state of majesty,
that none can relish but dilated greatness.
Vouchsafe to view the structure of a scene
That stands on tragic solid passion,
Oh that's fit traffic to commerce with births:
Strained from the mud of base unable brains,
Give them a scene may force their struggling blood
Rise up on tiptoe in attention,
And fill their intellect with pure elixed wit,
Oh that's for greatness apt, for princes fit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dar'st thou then undertake to suit our ears,
With such rich vestment.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Dare; yes my prince I dare, nay more, I will,
And I'll present a subject worth thy soul:
The honoured end of Cato Utican.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who'll personate him.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Marry that will I on sudden without change.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Thou wantest a beard.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Tush a beard ne'er made Cato, though many men's Cato hang only on their chin.
sp.l: Suppose this flower the city Utica,
The time the night that prolonged Cato's death:
Now being placed 'mong his philosophers,
These first discourse the soul's eternity.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Cato grants that I am sure, for he was valiant, and honest, which an epicure ne'er was, and a coward never will be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Then Cato holds a distinct notion,
Of individual actions after death:
This being argued his resolve maintains,
A true magnanimous spirit should give up dirt
To dirt, and with his own flesh dead his flesh,
Fore chance should force it crouch unto his foe:
To kill ones self some I, some hold it no,
Oh these are points would entice away ones soul:
To breaks indenture of base prentisage,Enter Francisco.
And run away from's body in swift thoughts
To melt in contemplation luscious sweets,
now my voluptuous Duke I'll feed thy sense,
Worth his creation: give me audience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My liege my royal liege, hear, hear my suit.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Now may thy breath ne'er smell sweet as long as thy lungs can pant for breaking my speech, thou Muscovite, thou stinking perfumer.

div.stage: Enter Albano.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is not this Albano our some times courtier?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No troth but Francisco your always perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Lorenzo Celso our brave Venice Duke, Albano Belletzo, thy merchant, thy soldier, thy courtier, thy slave, thy anything, thy what thou wilt, kisseth thy noble blood, do me right or else I am canonised a cuckold, canonised a cuckold, I am abused, I am abused, my wife's abused, my clothes abused, my shape, my house my all abused, I am sworn out of myself, beated out of myself baffled, jeered at, laughed at, barred my own house, debarred my own wife, whilst others swill my wines, gourmandize my meat, meat, kiss my wife, oh gods, oh gods, oh gods, oh gods, oh gods.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Who is't? who is't?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come sweet this is your waggery i'faith, as if you knew him not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes I fear I do too well, would I could slide away invisible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Assured this is he.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.l: My worthy liege the jest comes only thus.
Now to stop and cross it with mere like deceit:
All being known the French knight hath disguised,
A fiddler like Albano too, to fright the perfumer, this is all.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Art sure 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: 'Tis confessed 'tis right.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: It is right, 'tis true, right, I am a fiddler, a fiddler, a fiddler uds fut a fiddler; I'll not believe thee thou art a woman, and 'tis known veritas non querit angulos, truth seeks not to lurk under varthingalls, veritas non querit angulos, a fiddler?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Worthy sir pardon, and permit me first to confess yourself, your deputation dead hath made my love live, to offend you.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Ay, mock on, scoff on, flout on, do do do.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Troth sir in serious.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I good, good, come hither Celia,
Burst breast, rive heart asunder? Celia
Why startest thou back: seest thou this Celia
Oh me how often with lascivious touch thy lip,
Hath kissed this mark? how oft this much wronged breast
Hath born the gentle weight of thy soft cheek?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: O me my dearest lord, my sweet, sweet love.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What a fiddler, a fiddler? now thy love.
I am sure thou scornest; it nay Celia, I could tell
What on the night before I went to sea,
And took my leave with hymeneal rights
What, thou lisped
Into my ear, a fiddler and perfumer now.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: And —

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Dear brother.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.l: Most respected signior,
Believe it by the sacred end of love,
What much, much wrong hath forced your patience
Proceeded from most dear affied love,
Devoted to your house.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Believe it brother.

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.p: Nay yourself when you shall hear the occurrences will say 'tis happy, comical.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Assure thee brother.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Shall I be brave, shall I be myself now, love, give me thy love, brothers give me your breasts, French knight reach me thy hand, perfumer thy fist. Duke I invite thee, love I forgive thee: Frenchman I hug thee, I'll know all, I'll pardon all, and I'll laugh at all.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: And I'll curse you all.
O ye ha' interrupt a scene.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Quadratus we will hear these points discussed,
With apter and more calm affected hours.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Well, good, good.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Wast even so i'faith why then capricious mirth,
Skip light moriscoes in our frolic blood,
Flagged veins, sweet, plump with fresh infused joys:
laughter pucker our cheeks, make shoulders shog,
With chucking lightness, love once more thy lips,
For ever clasp our hands, our hearts, our crests,
Thus front, thus eyes, thus cheek, thus all shall meet.
Shall clip, shall hug, shall kiss, my dear, dear sweet,
Duke wilt thou see me revel, come love dance,
Court gallants court; suck amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Beauty your heart.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: First sir accept my hands.
She leaps too rash, that falls in sudden bands.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Shall I despair? never will I love more.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: No sea so boundless vast but hath a shore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why marry me.
Thou canst have but soft flesh, good blood, sound bones.
And that which fills up all your bracks, good stones.

sp.speaker: Lyzabet.
sp.l: Stones, trees and beasts in love still firmer prove,
Than man, I'll none no holdfasts in your loves.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Since not the mistress, come on faith the maid:

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Ten thousand ducats too to boat are laid.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why then wind cornets ▪ lead on jolly lad.

sp.speaker: Alla.
sp.l: Excuse me gallants though my legs lead wrong ▪
'Tis my first footing, wind out nimble tongue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well, how shall we spend this night ▪

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Gulp Rhenish wine my liege ▪ let our paunch rent ▪
Suck merry jellies, preview but not prevent
No mortal can the miseries of life.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I home invite you all, come sweet, sweet wife,
My liege vouchsafe thy presence, drink till the ground look blue, boy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Live still springing hopes, still in fresh new joys,
May your love's happy hit in fair cheeked wives,
Your flesh still plump with sapped restoratives,
That's all my honest frolic heart can wish,
A fico for the mew and envious pish,
Till night, I wish good food and pleasing day,
sp.p: But then found rest so ends or slight writ play. Exeunt.

div.stage: Deo open: max gratias.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
